description: Number of non-unitary divisors of n.
comments: Number of zeros in row n of table A225817; a(n) = A000005(n) - A034444(n); for n > 1: a(n) = A000005(n) - 2 * A007875(n). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Jul 30 2013
links: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: a[ n ]=Sigma(0, n)-2^r(n), where r()=A001221, the number of distinct primes dividing n.Dirichlet g.f.: zeta(s)^2 - zeta(s)^2/zeta(2*s). - _Geoffrey Critzer_, Dec 10 2014
example: Example 1: If n is squarefree (A005117) then a[ n ]=0 since all divisors are unitary. Example 2: n=12, d[ n ]=6, ud[ n ]=4, nud[ 12 ]=d[ 12 ]-ud[ 12 ]=2; from {1,2,3,4,6,12} {1,3,4,12} are unitary while {2,6} are not unitary divisors.Example 3: n=p^k, a true prime power, d[ n ]=k+1, u[ d ]=2^r[ x ]=2, so nud[ n ]=d[ p^k ]-2=k+1 i,e, it can be arbitrary large.
prog: (Haskell)a048105 n = length [d | d <- [1..n], mod n d == 0, gcd d (n `div` d) > 1]-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Aug 17 2011(PARI) a(n)=my(f=factor(n)[,2]); prod(i=1,#f,f[i]+1)-2^#f \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Sep 18 2015
author: _Labos Elemer_
